settings.title: Profile
settings.explain_browser_storage: When you change your answers in the calculator, for convenience they will be saved in your browser's storage. They are not stored on a server anywhere so your data remains private and only accessible by you on this browser. To erase your answers from browser storage and re-initialize default values, click the button below.

electric_vehicle.label: Purchase electric vehicle

content.description: I will trade in one of my vehicles:
And buy a more efficient electric vehicle that gets
I can sell my current vehicle for
And purchase a new one for

assumptions.description: Well-to-pump emissions: 20% of fossil fuel emissions. This includes emissions from the fuel used to find, extract, transport and refine crude oil into gasoline.
Greenhouse gas emissions from vehicles manufacturing: 53 grams CO2e per mile (8 metric tons per vehicle / 150,000 miles lifespan).
Not included: emissions from road construction and maintenance, and other government-related emissions.

electric_vehicle.fact: Americans are choosing greener vehicles--the average fuel efficiency of cars on the road in the U.S. has gone up steadily for the past 10 years. Don't get left behind in a gas guzzler!

rebates.text: Find rebates and incentives for this action

ride_my_bike.label: Ride my bike

assumptions.description: with a corresponding carbon footprint of about
Driving your vehicle the same distance produces

Growing, processing and distributing food produces greenhouse gases. The average American consumes about about 300 - 500 unnecessary calories per day, and riding a bicycle burns about 400 calories per hour, so most people could ride a bicycle for about one hour per day without increasing calorie intake. However, if you do not take in surplus calories and would need to eat more to fuel bicycle riding, then select Include emissions from food.

ride_my_bike.fact: Your bicycle can make you a lean, green clean-moving machine! Free tools like google maps have bike-friendly directions to get you going as an exemplary neighborhood cyclist.

assumptions.description: Carbon intensity of different transit options (gCO2e/passenger mile):
Diesel bus (average occupancy of bus is 11 passengers)
Natural gas bus (average occupancy is 11 passengers)
Electric transit rail (average occupancy is 37 passengers per rail car)
Amtrak (average occupancy is 23 passengers per rail car)

take_public_transportation.fact: Riding transit frees you from the stress of navigating traffic and provides time for work, catching up on the news or finally getting around to that book you've been meaning to read.

reduce_air_travel.label: Reduce air travel

content.description: By teleconferencing or staying home I will fly

assumptions.description: Flying produces 223 grams of CO2e/passenger mile, on average (WRI-WBCSD).
Indirect emissions (from contrails and other atmospheric effects) account for 50% of total emissions.

reduce_air_travel.fact: Travelling virtually is one of the best things you can do to reduce you impacts because every two-hours flight avoided saves as much as avoiding a month of typical driving.

A large portion of your savings come from reduced AC use as a result of increased shading and a reduction in outside temperature. Trees also reduce heating by lowering wind speed.

low_carbon_diet.label: Eat a low carbon diet

content.description: Use the selectors below to choose your new diet. How much of the following will each person eat daily (calories per day)?

assumptions.description: Food prices are based on average U.S. prices for each category of food items (meat, dairy, fruits & vegetables, cereals and other). The actual carbon footprint and price of food you purchase may vary substantially from these values

low_carbon_diet.fact: A third of all food emissions in the United States come from red meat and dairy products, while chicken and vegetables have up to ten times smaller footprints per serving, so small diet switches can make a BIG difference.

go_organic.label: Go organic

content.description: Currently, there is not conclusive scientific evidence that organic food, in general, has lower greenhouse gas emissions than conventional products. However, there are a lot of environmental reasons to buy organic food including reducing chemical toxins in the environment and encouraging sustainable farming practices, which frequently accompany organic farming.

assumptions.description: Price of Organics vs Conventional food products:

go_organic.fact: Organic products are available in nearly 20,000 natural foods stores, and are sold in nearly three-quarters of all conventional grocery stores.
